title: Grip Handle for a 5.25 Inch Desktop's Drive Bay

description.text:
This is a grip to insert into a desktop computer's 5.25 inch drive bay.

Rationale

With optical drives going out of fashion, 5.25 Inch bays are no longer of much use. Leaving them empty makes for an handy carrying grip. However, such an opening is a gateway for dust entering the computer case. Moreover, sharp edges inside the case may endanger the health of the carrying person. This grip closes inserts into an unused 5.25 inch bay, providing a safe grip and dust protection.

Customisation

Parameters for material strenght and grip depth can be customised in the scad file. I also enabled the Customizer, but that does not seem to work. Any help with fixing that would be most welcome.

Printing

There is a step around the front, so the best way of printing is probably to turn the grip on its front and print it from front to rear upwards.

Installation

It is most ergonomical to install the grip into the top most drive bay. That way, the carrying hand to wrap around the edge to the top of the case. The other hand can grip at the rear of the case beneath the power supply unit or the opposing edge of the case. Installing the grip into the top of the case also enables the user to line the case in order to support the grip for increased stability.

Status

I made some changes after publishing this file. Critically, the tap holes had the wrong size. Please make sure you have the latest version.

GitHub

This Thing is also available on GitHub.

100%

description.text:
This is just a simple camera web cam mount. It slips onto the aluminum bed to allow the camera to move with the bed keeping the distance the same while shooting time-lapse videos of your prints. I designed it for a 2mm thick aluminum plate.

It requires a square 1/4 20 nut and threaded 1/4 20 rod. I designed the pocket tight and filed util it fit in tightly.

These are the square nuts I used : http://amzn.to/1XnqOWR

the 1/4 20 threaded rod can be purchased at any home improvement store

UPDATE :: So while this works the design amplifies any Y axis vibrations. It does not affect the print but the camera vibrates... I'm going to look at what I can do to dampen this this week...

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

FolgerTech 3030 i3

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed with ABS as it mounts right under the heatbed. PLA might work but I wanted to make sure.

Using small file to open the pocket just enough for the nut to fit.

Screw the 1/4 20 threaded rod into the nut and cut the rod about three treads up from the top of the printed part. If you find that when you tighten your camera down it points the wrong way back remove the nut and re-install 180 degrees, if it points two the left or right install it turned 90 degrees to compassionate.

title: Snap-On Dial Gauge holder for Prusa I3 Zonestar P802Q, P802N and others

description.text:
You can watch a video how it works if you look in the "Thing Files" tab above (open with VLC).

The holder is designed to connect cheap chinese dial gauges like this one http://www.ebay.de/itm/191381928182?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT to the extruder, to achieve a very accurate bed leveling in a short time without any electronics.
After the mount is added, the dial gauge can be very easily removed and added within seconds simply by pressing/jamming it inside(no screwdriver needed), so it doesn't add much weight to the extruder while printing.

The mount itself is simply screwed onto the extruder with two long M3 screws and stays there. It's very light.

I've printed mine in PETG, 0.3mm layer height, 30% honeycomb infill and it works like a charm.
Of course no support necessary for printing

A filament guide so the filament does not shave against upper threaded rods.
Can set height and a few other parameters to fit your printer, made for my prusa mendel, but will work for most printers

Prusa Mendel Metric

Doesn't Matter

No

0.2mm layers

30%

Notes:

Should print with any settings, probably. Nothing complicated. I used a 0.4 tip, 0.2mm layer height, This fit very snugly onto the rods, when still warm from printing. No post celan-up for me, if you don't count peeling off the raft I used.

Openscad is a fantastic program :-)
Had some problems designing the arcs for the inner curves. solution was picked up from middle school when we learned how to draw curves with a ruler...School wasn't a complete waste of time after all.

First version used booth openings for the rod-holds outwards, thought it would be more springy than it was, decidedly bettre to use one side outwards and one downwards, so it can be rotated onto the printer.

Parameters

rod_distance = 58; //distance between rods.. duh

rod_diameter = 8; // standard prusa rods, if you use m10 please set this to 10
rod_tolerance = 0.2; //first try was terribly snug, ie only posiible to screw on...

holder_width = 15; // the width of the stuff that holds it onto the rods
holder_thickness = 1.4; how much force is needed to install this 0.67*2~1.4
holder_opening = 90; //degrees, less will make it difficult to install, more make it more likely to fall off

guide_width = 5; // the diameter of the ring on top
guide_diameter = 10; // the guides inner hole diameter
guide_opening = 5; //mm for 3mm filament
height = 30; //distance above rods for the filament hole

Tank tread system includes Treads, Pins, Boogies, Idlers, and gears.

Filament Guide for Ultimaker 2 - Final version

This guide is used when the spool is rotated by 90 degrees behind the printer. The 90 degree rotation can be usefull to force the filament ripples of the extruder to the side of the bowden and PTFE coupler. This mod helped me to get rid of a lot of underextrusions as the friction of the ripples inside the PFE coupler was very high.

You need:
M3x14 and a washer to mount the base to the UM2 below the extruder. This replaces an original screw of the left motor covers.
A M5x20 with a nut to fix the arm at the base plate.
A 606 ball bearing to keep the wheel moving

Assembly:
Press the ballbearing in the wheel an click it on the arm.
Fix the arm with the M5 screw at the base plate in the desired angle.
Remove the original motor cover screw from your UM2 and mount the FilaGuide with the new screw and the washer instead.
Fill the cleaner/oiler block with your cleaning/oiling material and push the filament through the holes.

Update: V5 of the Base is done to minimize friction and to make filament exchange easier if no cleaner/olier is used.

Before printing, please check the size.
To get the real dimensions I had to draw the model by increasing the measures of the 4%.
I had to replace the original screws with other longer (M2.5x8 mm).
I published the file to be easily and freely modified.
If you improve the project, let me know.
If you want to support me you can always donate to my paypal account (https://www.paypal.me/birrozza). Thanks

----- Translation / Traduzione -----

Prima di stampare, controllare le dimensioni.
Per avere le giuste dimensioni, ho dovuto disegnare il modello incrementando le misure del 4%.
Ho dovuto sostituire le viti originali con altre più lunghe (M2.5x8 mm).
Ho pubblicato il file del disegno per essere facilmente e liberamente modificato.
Se migliorate il progetto, avvisatemi.
Per supportarmi, fare una donazione sul mio account PayPal (https://www.paypal.me/birrozza)
Grazie

author: SanJager

description.text:
I saw some LM8LUU printed bearings which take some of the features of the IGUS Drylin bearings concepts, they didn't have the circlip indents of the LM8LUU as well as having square corners on the inner fin angles.

So I designed 2 new LM8LUU bearings with the circlip indents and also added fillets to the inner fin corners. There is a 12 and 18 teeth version, I have made a 28 teeth version but not printed and this may well not be achievable with good results (if anyone prints this I would like to see).

Printed these at 100 microns, 3 shells (which effectively makes it 100% infil almost) and I also dropped the outline edge speed to 35% of the max (50mm/s normal). As can be seen my vertical is a little off so will look into that, but otherwise the models should be dimensionally accurate to the LM8LUU.

I have some circlips on order and intend to fit these on my Wanhao Duplicator i3 once they arrive, will see how they perform compared to a each other and a standard bearing. These are made in PLA, cannot print PET or Nylon at the minute but both would probably be a better alternative and Nylon I think would potentially work really well.

**Update added a 10 teeth version, IGUS part number this closely matches is RJ4JP-01-08 but this is a 45mm version. The image for this on the website shows 12 teeth, but when I looked at the drawing it shows 10!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

100 microns

Infill:

90-100%

comments.text: Being slightly impatient waiting for the actual Drylin or finding high quality LM8LUU bearings, I'm going to print these out at 45mm long. I was thinking that with a scrap piece of 8mm smooth rod -heated up just past the temp to deform PLA or ABS I would be able to get a perfect fit sliding the heated rod through to more or less burnish the inside diameter of the bearings. Anyone tried doing that to perfect the size?
comments.author: Wasatch

comments.text: Yeah, wiped some vegetable oil on the actual rod , heated with a lighter till the oil went black , popped the bush on and used the rod like a rolling pin , slide up and down a few times ..... reheat and repeat till it's perfect

author: oet

description.text:
The base radius and the height of the cylinder are designed to be equal, r.
Therefore the volume of the cylinder is given by

pi r^2 r = pi * r^3

If we make 4 such cylinders, then the total volume will be 4 pi r^3

Then we made a sphere with radius equal to the base radius of the cylinder. Print 3 such spheres with 0% infill such that water can be poured into them.

The water poured out from these 3 spheres should be able to fill the 4 cylinders,
therefore the volume of each sphere is given by

4 pi r^3 /3 = 4/3 pi r^3

https://youtu.be/8LbeQutuRfY

remixed_from.title: Hinged Box With Latch, Somewhat Parametric and Printable In One Piece

description.text: Derived from my hinged box with latch, I remixed it a bit and sized it for a 20 pack of death.

This print is a real pain so good luck with it. It covers a pretty large area so make sure your bed is super level. My design creates a pretty large bride on the part the retains the smokes in the box, if you have good print settings then you won't see any droops or strings whatsoever.  
The hinge is plenty loose. I promise this hinge will not print fused. It will swing freely as soon as you pull it off the bed. Push in on the wall with the latch to open and close it easier.  
I use the Makerware Standard print setting on a Rep2.

comments.text: Can you post the cad file please? And thanks in advance.
comments.author: xaliax

comments.text: Can't post the cad file since this thing was made with a major mashup of tools. The main box is modeled in Solidworks. The hinge, latch and latch retainer are made in OpenSCAD and the death and skull are cut with Blender. If you measure a 100 cig and tell me how long it is, I'll post a new version. Also, you could simply scale the Y dimension in your slicing software and the whole design should still hold up and print in one piece with no problems. Also, if you're good with Solidworks, OpenSCAD and blender, just send me a private message and I'll send you all the sources.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Bearing block LM8LUU for Y axis

description.text:
(Update 17/03/2016)
So I came across a couple of problems with the design and I have now made the following changes: Corrected the positioning of the holes. Made the circlip grooves longer. Enlarged the bearing hole (was too tight). Finally I changed the way in which the nuts are added to the block; they now slide in from the side instead of being forced in from the top.

Bearing blocks that are similar to the stock design but are meant to house LM8LUU bearings. Screw positioning is based on measurements and the measurements of SC8UU blocks (as on this site http://www.3dprintingstore.co.za/mechanics/linear-bearing-with-housing-sc8uu/).

You will need:
A pair of circlip pliers.
The M4 screws that hold the bearing blocks to the platform.
12 M4 nuts.
A thin screwdriver or allen key to position nuts.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I suggest using "lines" support as they are easier to remove. The orientation of printing is your choice. Perhaps it is better to avoid support (and the associated surface deterioration) where the bearings will be housed though.

Assembly

Print the parts. (1x offset 2x normal).
Put the M4 nuts into their places. (They go into the slots with the flat sides against the "walls").
Remove the old bearing blocks.
Remove the circlips from the old bearing blocks.
Fit the long bearings into the printed bearing blocks.
Insert the circlips.
Fit the new blocks to the platform using the old screws.
Reassemble.

That should do it.

comments.text: Nice, I was looking for a upgrade for the Y axis, maybe I'll remix it to fit 2 lm8luu on the right side by stretching the block.
comments.author: Dutchy_79

comments.text: Both are for the Y-axis (the axis on which the bed moves). The one is just "offset" so that you don't have to modify your end-stop switches.

author: rossgve

description.text:
This is a device to quickly and easily patch a mosquito net. Mosquito nets are one of the simplest and effective ways of reducing the chance of contracting Malaria. The net is used to protect a sleeping person from biting insects, especially mosquitos. It is critical that the net is tucked in all around the sleeping area, and that no part of the person under the net is in direct contact with the net. The device patches the net, or secures a spare piece of mesh to patch the hole.   
Holes or tears in the net compromise the effectiveness. Sewing can be used to repair tears, but this can be labour intensive and a poorly sewn repair also leaves openings for mosquitos. When a hole is burnt in the net, sewing without a patch can cause bunching, reducing the effective size of the net.  
A 1.2 mm x 1.2 mm mesh will block mosquitos. Smaller mesh sizes can be used to block other biting insects; however airflow can be significantly reduced. This is a concern in hot climates.  
I would like to experiment to determine the minimum achievable mesh size. I feel like the pegs and their snap locking mechanism will also need some adjustment before the device works really well.  
This locking mechanism could be used to attach clips, weights, or decorations for children to nets.

If you have a spare peice of mesh, then just print the If you have a spare piece of mesh, then just print the "NetFixerSquareBacking" and the "NetFixerSquare".  
Place the spare piece of mesh over the hole, and then work the pegs of the fixer through both pieces of mesh. Work the pegs through the holes on the backing. They should snap into place. Depending on the type of mesh (silk vs cotton vs steel) you may have to change the length of the pegs, distance between them, or diameter.  
If you don't have a spare piece of mesh, print the "NetPatchCircle" and the backing, and repeat above without the spare piece of mesh.

My brother's computer seemed to have a bad video card (failed intermittently), but rather than having to poke around replacing capacitors, it turned out it's cooling fan's plastic blades were cracked, keeping it from rotating. So I printed up a new one.

title: Alternate Frame for Blade 350QX
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a work in progress.

I designed this frame to transfer the Blades 350QX v1 electronics to.
Hopefully lighter and without the need to upgrade anything.
Frame size: 360 (Diagonally 366mm from center of motor to motor.)
14mm X 14mm motor bolt pattern (Blade motors)

inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34552
DJI made the Flame Wheel 330, 156g ,HobbyKing's clone F330 147g (without hardware i believe) but these frames are smaller.

ABS
1 arm: 20g or 0.8oz (4 arms) 80 grams so far
I will have to try making some with less infill and see how strong it is.
Body plates: TBD

Update 6/13/2017: I came across a carbon fiber frame and I never printed the top and bottom plate to try. Please share your results.

The PDF is a 3d drawing, giving you a 360 view. Open in Acrobat or Microsoft Edge.

Custom CoreXY

Yes

author: Donloop

description.text:
A little two part snap thing to keep your cabinet securely closed. I needed one to keep my cabinet closed because my fat cat (who's on a new diet) has resorted to opening it up and chewing through rice and dry pinto bean bags.
It stays closed very securely, but it turns out he can still get in there. So I guess I'll make something like one of those child locks next.
And yes, apparently I wont go to the drug store and buy these things for like 50 cents.
Both parts print out in one file.  As pictured, screw the male part to the door and screw the female inside. Nice.

Parametric Recorder Flute.

This is an approximation of a wooden recorder (see photo). This recorder really works (tested in PLA), but the sound of course is not as good as the original wooden recorder.

To build a single recorder, following printed items are required:

  • RecorderTopWithoutCore.stl
  • RecorderTopCore.stl
  • BottomFlutePart1.stl
  • BottomFlutePart2.stl
  • BottomFlutePart3.stl

Scotch tape has been used to connect the parts more securely (see photo).

For an improved version of this design see:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1433075

print_settings.Notes:: The two prebuilt hangers pretty much fills the Ultimaker bed.  There is nothing special required.  You are printing this upside down for a flat top.

title: Test Lead Holder -basic and varied width

description.text:
Basic Test lead holder for cables up to 6.35mm (RG-6 with connector). You can fit your meter, generator and power leads on this hanger. Holes for wall mount or if not a lot of weight some two sided tape may work.

All the STL files have been fixed (disconnected parts seen in some slicers) Cura was fine with the original STL's.

There are supports about 2/3 the finger length to handle higher weights for lots of cables. Maybe over built. The varied width hanger is a lighter build.

I have an updated SCAD file (1.1) up to add or take slots away, trim sides plus other configurable pieces, enjoy.

Let me know what you think.
David

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The two prebuilt hangers pretty much fills the Ultimaker bed. There is nothing special required. You are printing this upside down for a flat top.

title: Light Ramp for Hobby King Desert Fox

description.text:
The ramp is designed to mount two pairs of the Turnigy High Power Headlight System as available on Hobby King on a Desert Fox car.

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__58321__Turnigy_High_Power_Headlight_System.html

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__76301__H_King_34_Desert_Fox_34_ARR_1_10_4WD_RC_Desert_Racer_EU_Warehouse_.html

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Update March 20th:
I realized that no matter how to place the object for print there will be weak cross sections. So, i split it into two components. You may download the v2 and print the attachment bars "flat" to increase strength.

Also, it will save quite a bit of needed support material. :)

I recommend printing it with the "front" facing down. But I have no idea how to flip an object on thingiverse.

Ok, 100% infill is not strictly required, buut it seem sensible. :=)
I recommend pusing them in from the front side. Make sure the cooling fins does not catch on the rear edge of the housing.

author: Janjoh

print_settings.Notes:: If you notice I went with two-tone.  At .2mm resolution, I paused in the beginning of line 10 and again at line 13 (so the back and face would be the same color).

description.text:
Thanks to flurin for providing the Customizable Hair Band! I dropped it into Tinkercad and added some cat ears for the extra girly flair. My girls love them! I had to share.

One is labelled kitty versus cat; it's just the size of ears. Also, check out the Bunny Ears.

Note: Don't forget to cut off the tabs, they are present to act as a strategic brim to help bed adhesion and prevent curling.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

80%

Notes:

If you notice I went with two-tone. At .2mm resolution, I paused in the beginning of line 10 and again at line 13 (so the back and face would be the same color).

The three pictures of my daughter is actually one of the same. For the outer layers I used UV Sensitive PLA and Glow-in-the-dark PLA. The UV is semi-translucent so when the inner layer glows it actually diffuses and provides some definition which was unexpected.

Yeah, I've been calling him FrostByte... too much? I think it's too much. Oh well.
A little light-up snow man for the holidays! I carved a piece of filament into an orange nose; the jaggedness makes it look like a carrot. I may add some copper wire arms (to look like sticks) but they might not be very pleasing to the eye in contrast to his roundness.

Print out the body and the hat and glue them together. Then dress him up however you see fit. A scarf might look nice if he can pull it off.
Theres a spot underneath for a cr2032 battery (3.3v), but it makes a cool little figurine even not lit up. I'll let you take it from there.

comments.text: It's a BABY snowman!  Big head and big eyes make anything look 'baby-like' (and therefore cute).  Maybe call it the FrostyBittyByte?

remixed_from.author: MazaaFIN
remixed_from.title: Smooth X-axis for Prusa i3 with Leadscrews

description.text:
When upgrading my P3Steel with some Z-Axis lead screws I couldn't find any system I really liked. I liked toolson's X-axis system but it uses the standard threaded rod. Based the main dimensions off of MazaaFIN's Smooth X-axis, added a mounting point for toolson's Z-axis endstop trigger, and made 2 different tensioner's.

Designed for 8mm lead screws using the T8 nuts with a 17mm center-to-center distance between the linear rod and lead screw. The tensioner's use M5 bolts and nuts, one variant uses a M5 square nut instead of a hex. Everything else should be standard M3 stuff. This should work with any X-Axis carriage if it keeps with the original linear rod spacing.

Currently in the process of printing to verify it works well.

Update: Clearances are super tight on the models, Linear bearing slot is 15mm diameter, lead screw nut is 10.2mm and X-axis rod holes are 8.1mm. Also forgot to make the slot on the [x_axis_tensioner_with_pulley.xtl] big enough to get the pulley in in the first place. It might still work if you're not the using 18mm diameter toothed idler. I'll be fixing the tensioner in the next couple days and will either upload some other parts with bigger clearances or just the model file so people can adjust to their needs.

Update 2: Fixed the tensioner with pulley so it now has a opening in the back as large as the cutout, also uploaded all the solidworks files. Got it set up on my P3Steel with the two piece tensioner a few days ago and it works great.

With these mounts I build a box around my 3d printer. The 3d printer itself is mounted on a 25 mm thick board. The maximum plate thickness is 4 mm.
keil.stl is a small wedge if the plate thickness is lower than 4 mm
klammer.stl is a small clamb for the top plate to hold it more stable and also to form a small gap for the filament
box.stel.stl is the mount for the foots
box1.stl and box2.stl are the mounts for the top plate.
to make it real stable it is good to screw the mounts to the board and also to screw the top plate. To access the printer the front plexiglas can be simply removed by pull it up (a handle griff.stl can be screwed to the pexiglas).

description.text: I recently started working for the county (I used to work construction) and we send out large amounts of notification letters (I also plan on using this when I send out wedding invitations in the near future!!). I designed this in Autocad to the size I thought would work. After a first messed up print I decided I could cut the size in half. PLS NOTE YOU WILL DEFINITELY NEED TO SCALE THIS OBJECT DOWN.

Hictop 3D-P11

Notes:

I printed this at a finer resolution and than acetone vapor bathed the base part to make sure no water leaked out. Do whatever you feel you need to.

This is a complete filament spool holder. You can use this to hang a spool from a metal pipe or clothes pole. While the intent was to reduce friction on the spool and let it turn more easily than the factory supplied one, I may have over done it a little.

Print HangerL, HangerR, ConnectorM, and 2 SpoolEnd. They will snap together and look like the picture.

The OpenSCAD file in included. The code is crude but you can change the parameters to fit other pole or spool sizes. If the spool spins too easily you can increate the pin and hole diameters.

I suggest using a fill density of 50% or setting the width up by a mm. I will be posting a refined scad program when I have time to clean it up.

description.text:
A set of CD dividers to keep a physical music collection organized.

I don't have files for the customizer, but if you want to customize these you can on Tinkercad: https://www.tinkercad.com/users/1y9R7C9M0KV-purelynicole

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select (Wanhao Duplicator I3)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

25%

Notes:

This print is VERY sensitive to bed leveling, since it spans the almost the entirety of a 200mm x 200mm bed. I have added a "level test" file that takes roughly 30% of the time to print as one divider, to let you know if there are any issues before taking on a full size print.

For best results, print at a .1 base layer to get a smooth appearance on both sides.

This is my "start learning Tinkercad" project. I measured a CD, and created the dividers based on that size. The 1" letter was chosen because that's how much more room I have on my shelf. The Hex pattern is to save time/filament.

Are you tired of those boring door bells? Looking for something better? Embrace your inner geek and let all of your guests know how awesome you are with this retro style door bell! Featuring an arcade momentary push-button, it connects to any standard doorbell or garage door opener. The button features a smooth press and release. Installation is super simple and easy. The three piece design allows your to snap the pieces together while the back cover is screws in as standard cover plate. The button is very responsive and allows you to rapidly press it. It feels awesome each time you ring that bell or open that garage door. Watch the video

This project uses a 33mm momentary push button from Sparkfun. The front and back covers snap together onto the frame. The back cover should be screwed into the panel before snapping the pieces together. The three parts are printed without any support and sliced using MakerWare high quality setting. 0.2mm layer height
20% infill
90/150 travel rates

description.text:

This 45 degree bevel cutter uses standard utility blades and was designed to be used on dollar tree foam board. It works great for cutting bevels for folds and hinges for control surfaces!

This bevel cutter is designed to use 3 M3x10mm screws.

I suggest printing this with 10% infill and 10% support.

If you have any suggestions for tweaks or modifications please let me know!

Like all my other uploads, this item is also for sale on my website at http://RcPartsHangar.com.

description.text:
TL;DR: Use updated version. Pics show old vs new. Works great. Get back to shaving.

I got a Simpson pure badger shaving brush. Didn't like how it sat on the counter in my way, and didn't like not being able to hang it upside down to dry. So I made this. piece of double stick tape on the back, or figure out how to put your own suction cups on the back. I'll probably play around with the design- I already noticed I missed a spot cleaning up the bottom right edge.

USE REVISED STL FILE. cleaned it up.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I chose 100% because I minimized the structure as much as possible when creating this. I may upload a bulkier one that can be printed with 15% infill later. I also always default to support and raft because a little more wasted filament is cheaper than a lot of my wasted time. play around with it!

description.text:
This thing is a filament colorizer for the Robo 3D R1 or R1+ it fits in the slot at the top of the printer and the filament is threaded through it. A Sharpie Chisel Tip marker felt tip must first be slit with a razor so the filament can ride in the slot. It is inserted into the hole on the front side and oriented so the tip angle is vertical in line with the filament. As the filament passes over the marker color is applied. The newly colored filament then enters the extruder where the color mixes with the plastic and is extruded.

Note: The color of the final print may not match the Sharpie color, it depends on the type of filament. It is Recommended to use White or Clear filament for best results.

Tip: Print samples to determine the final color each of your Sharpies and filaments will produce for reference.

Remove support material.

title: Kryptex as container programmable no glue da vinci code  geocaching container

description.text:
i saw a nice Kryptex http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:619853 but you have to glue the case. No, I don't like the final situation. no maintenance possible.

my Kryptex is full programmable only when its open. You can change the Code how often you want.

I hope you have fun with it.

Please print with support.
Rotate 180 degrees in X) to print it as I thought it might print better with the teeth upwards
If you warm the parts with a hot air gun then your pressure inaccuracies will disappear.
Simply heat both rows of teeth (only lightly) then press on a table. Both must be flush only then fit all the rings.
You have to open the kryptex and you can use one ore two screwdrivers to retract the spring.

Dimensions:70mm x 95mm outside and 37mm x75mm inside.

description.text:
I just got my Galaxy S7 and tried to find a case to print but couldn't find one so I made one. I printed this using PETG which is both and strong and flexible enough to work.

Enjoy and please post pictures of yours if you print one.

7/18/2016 -
After using the new case for a few days and from your feedback I updated the design. I added slots on the back to provide better grip and let the heat out. I added grips on the side and I also enlarged and better positioned some of the holes

comments.text:
I printed this thing this morning, and it's a little big. The phone slides up and down in the case, and the sides can be squeezed in, and there's probably a paper-thickness between the top of the phone and the lip of the case when I hold it firmly to the back. I'm going to try shrinking it by 5% in every dimension and see how that comes out. First try: Nozzle 0.25mm, 0.2mm layers. PLA on unheated glass with gluestick.
Update: 100% is a bit too big but still fits, 95% was WAY too small, and 98% is just right. I had to slide it in the top and then bend the sides out to get it in without forcing it. I'm not sure why other people are finding 100% to be tight. Maybe the nozzle size has something to do with it.

title: Fatshark Battery Clip for Zippy 1300 2S Lipo

description.text:
When my original Fatshark battery finally died, I replaced it with a Zippy 1300 2S Compact battery that I had lying around. That worked great, except that I would have to continuously keep putting the battery back into strap as it would fall out nearly every time I took the goggles off.

This is just a simple clip that holds the battery in the goggle strap. I added wing clips on both sides to grab the strap, and the holder itself is sized for a good fit with this battery. The little cap at the top is for balance lead storage.

Zippy Compact 1300mAh 2S 25C Battery:

description.text:
This is just my first try at this, it isn't perfect, you may have to widen the motor mount holes, sand some things..etc. So download if you want, but it isn't a final version.

I originally thought I'd put conards on it, thus the forward holes for a spar, but decided not to.

Also note, I accidentally made the distance from the motor mount to the end 200mm, leaving no shaft to stick out. So the whole pod file has the long tail, but the individual tail part is 15mm shorter.

Bearings used both for replacing motor bearings, and for supporting the shaft at the end of the pod: http://www.ebay.com/itm/251149974179?

200mm long 3mm shaft: http://www.ebay.com/itm/321896439905?

The pod's walls are made of two 1 layer thick walls separated by 3mm and 3% infill. Or you could just say 3mm thick hollow walls.

What software did you design this in? I use SOLIDWORKS and if your software can give me something to work with I'd be happy to digitally alter that 45degree angle. There are several commercially available devices especially designed to reduce the transmission of forces into the foot and leg from a detonating mine. This device was inspired by the spider boot. This article presents some of the benefits this device offers to users who are exposed to a mine blast: http://maic.jmu.edu/journal/4.2/focus/sb/spiderboot.htm. Mines are an unfortunate legacy of wars in many countries. For people who must work clearing mines or work in close proximity to known minefields, this device may be of use. In the event that the person sets off a mine, the device provides some separation from the explosion, as well as shielding the user from ejecta and absorbing some energy from the blast. The "arms" of the shoe are designed to blow off and distort in the event of a blast. The voids underneath the footplate act to distribute forces over the foot and absorb energy. There is room for improving this energy absorbing zone, potentially using a honeycomb or some other porous structure, perhaps making a "birds nest" with the polymer. Ensuring that the shoe is strong enough for walking and potentially running is also a priority. This may be especially important in hot climates, where high ambient temperatures could weaken the plastic, or at least make it more likely to creep.

This is a super easy one to print, other than the massive amount of plastic. The shoe should max out the work envelope on your machine, whatever that is. You want the footprint as large as possible.   
After it is printed, thread some webbing through the slots on the side, and strap on your sturdiest boot.  You may have to get creative to get a nice binding. A snowboard binding would be great to clip in, if you have one lying around. Otherwise, just use string. If you don't know knots, tie lots.

comments.text: Did you get this shoe design from a museum? Shoes exactly like yours were in use in ancient Persia to elevate people from the street so that they don't step on horse poop because people back then used horses for transportation. Being a fashion designer, I am always looking into really retro designs for inspiration for some really far out fashion. After all, if it looks "normal" and they can buy it in a store, why would they 3d print it? Only stuff that is truly special which you cannot buy from a store is 3d print worthy. Therefore, 3d printed fashion design has to be really far out and a little bit crazy.

description.text:
I was experiencing very strong astigmatism on my printer (circles coming out as ovals) regardless that square or rectangular shapes were coming out totally fine. So here is a quick calibration model combining both types of shapes I came out with in order to solve the problem with M92 adjustments.

Original dimensions :

  • Circle
    . Outer diameter 140.00 mm
    . Inner diameter 136.00 mm
    . Thickness 1.00 mm
  • Cross
    . Length in X and Y 120.00 mm
    . Width of arms 2.00 mm
    . Thickness 1.00 mm

Measurements meant to be made using a caliper directly on the COLD bed before removing (in case you have a heated bed like me).

For the circle I measured X direction, Y direction and +/-15°, +/-30°, +/-45°, +/-60° and +/-75° from my Y axis for more precision.

NB : If your first layer is thicker than the others, make sure you don't gab it with your caliper.

description.text:
Shown here is a study of the basic design for the PrintrBot. After analyzing the PrintrBot flicker stream, it was apparent that several versions were present. I picked and chose several design elements from multiple models and created an amalgamation shown here. Do not expect this to be an exact copy. Included is the SCAD file for manipulation. Pay attention to the notes and comments when making changes. I make no guarantee about the functionality or printablilty of parts. In order to make a functioning PrintrBot clone, you will also need the following parts: 8mm threaded rod
8mm rail
lmu88 (a bunch)
extruder, steppers, controller,etc... and here are some additional printed parts you will need: Idler Pulley for XAxis :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3970 - whosiswhatsis Timing Belt Pulley for X / Y Axis:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1362 - Erik
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2079 - NopHead
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6604 - makeme 5mm to 8mm shaft couplers:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11708 - Petehagoras
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10906 - raldrich Additionally, The Y-pulley idlers need to be designed to provide tension of the y-belt to the Y-Motor. Feel free to provide some constructive criticisms. If you make changes to a part, please send them to me.
-PMF

description.text:
Update 23.03.16

added a V2 version which allows you to use a rubber/spring between the shafts. Tighten one shaft to the rods using the M3s. The 2nd shaft will not be tightened to the rods. It will be connected via rubbers or springs (see picture). This way you can USE different filament spools without using a screwdriver to move a shaft. I also updated the RodDiameter to 17mm. It now has more space to move which stops the shaft from tilting when using rubber/springs.

title: V8R7-II FrSky receiver mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Receiver mount for the FrSky V8R7-II. In most cases it would be easiest to just attach with double sided tape.
However, I have included some mounting clip tabs which are designed to allow it to be attached to Eachine Racer 250. Simply insert the clips AFTER putting the mount in place on the racer 250 and then use a few drops of acetone to weld them in. (assuming you printed them in ABS)

The receiver basically just snaps into place (I use that term loosely). No need for zip ties, tape, etc.

The easiest thing to use for antenna wire supports is the 3mm coffee stirrer tubes that you can often get for free at convenience stores. The holes in the model are exactly 3mm, but you will probably have to drill them out very slightly to get the tubes to go in.

Why did I use the V8R7-II for my receiver rather than an D4R-II ???
Simple... I wanted to wire in transmitter activated LED control, and I also wanted to control the camera tilt in flight with my Taranis. (See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393669)
Couldn't do those on my Racer 250 with the D4R-II.

remixed_from.title: Decap tray for RCS reloading press

description.text:
I love the new primer catcher my RCBS Rock Chucker sports:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1223108

Might also work with this primer catcher:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148190

Or its predecessor:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84047

While it works well (much better than stock piece of sh!t), the spent primers are dumped onto the floor unless connected to a trash can with a 1/2" vinyl hose. I just taped a bag onto the spout, but it fell off after a bit.

Anyway, I don't have a hose, but I do have a 3D printer, so I made this Thing to catch the primers from the primer catcher, hence primer catcher catcher. There is also an optional countersunk #8 screw hole to keep it in place. Inside edges are blended to make removal of spent primers with fingers easier, should you choose to secure it, and to help with printing in recommended orientation.

There is a 75 mm version and a 100 mm version, that runs the entire length of the Rock Chucker. I did the 75 first to test fit, and it works well enough for me. If you're screwing it down it might make more sense to use the 100 mm version to hold more spent primers in between emptying. The model is fully parametric, so any length could be made if you can open the .prt file and edit the dimensions. (sorry no OpenSCAD)

Works best on a slightly angled surface, like this portable reloading bench I made:
http://precisionrifleblog.com/2012/11/12/portable-reloading-press-plans/

all credit for that goes to "Cal" from precisionrifleblog.com for the design of that stand. Pictures included in case you want to make your own! Only took me 4 hours or so, going slow and trying to be as precise as possible. But I did have the right tools for the job, so YMMV

Printer:

FFCreat0r

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

10$

Notes:

Print Catcher100V1.1.stl (the bigger one)

Recommended print orientation shown in Makerware picture. I use raft since I printed in ABS, but whatever works. PLA shouldn't need one. No supports, since edge blends should get the ends close enough to bridge as it reaches the top layers. File it down to fit if needed.

.2mm, 2 shells, 10% infill

Use #8 screw to secure to your reloading bench if desired

Resulting droop from no supports. Just scrape off with a knife

100 Large Rifle Primers 250 Large Rifle Primers (still room for more so I guess I was off with the capacity)

Took some very crude measurements with a caliper, modeled it up without a preliminary sketch, and printed. Works great and only took 30-60 min to design.

The fifth picture shows the Primer Catcher Catcher after decapping 100 cases. I'm estimating that it could hold 100 more (the 75 mm version, large rifle primers). Doing some math:

X, Y and Z thickness = 2 mm
75 mm vol: (75-22mm)(30-22mm)(24-2mm) = 40,612 mm^3
100: (100-22mm)(30-22mm)(24-2mm) = 54912 mm^3

Dividing yields 1.3521, so the 100 mm one has about 35% more volume, which should equate to 270-300 primers. So you can get an extra 100 primers into the bigger one. Just print that unless you're out of filament, I only made the smaller one because I didn't know if my crude measurements were refined enough.

comments.text: nice addition! Btw - a 1/2" inner diameter tube fits perfect on the primer catcher and this here can be used to plug it and collect the spent primers in the tube http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:924312

title: Ozark Trail hand pump to vacuum bag attachment.

description.text:
I store my filament in a garment storage vacuum bag with some desiccant, but when I change filament late at night I don't want the noise of firing up my vacuum to evacuate the bag.

I remembered we have a nice high volume low pressure air pump for inflating/deflating wading pools and air mattresses. But it didn't have any adapters that would fit the bag.

OpenSCAD to the rescue! Grabbed a funnel script I had found a few months back, tweaked the settings, added a few extra lines of code to add locking tabs. Works like a champ!

title: FrSky D4R-II / X4R 36x36mm receiver mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Receiver mount for the FrSky D4R-II. I believe it should also work with the X4R (same external dimensions). This particular mount is designed with 30.5mm hole spacing which matches popular flight controllers such as Naze32/Flip32, CC3D, etc.
Of course, you can mount it with double stick tape or any other method that you choose also.

The receiver basically just snaps into place (I use that term loosely). No need for zip ties, tape, etc.

The easiest thing to use for antenna wire supports is the 3mm coffee stirrer tubes that you can often get for free at convenience stores. The holes in the model are exactly 3mm, but you will probably have to drill them out very slightly to get the tubes to go in.

UPDATE 3/26:

New low profile version added with 20 degree from horizontal antenna wire angle. This is intended to be mounted on my Eachine Racer 250 battery tray.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1289398
The low angle permits the antenna wires to clear the upper frame plate. Antenna tube holes increased in diameter to 3.1mm to help eliminate the need to ream them with a drill.

comments.text: The model itself is very nicely designed. But I do not recommend it for X4R / X4R-SB as the left antenna hole is 3mm off and cause bad bending.

title: IR Remote Tester
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I play a lot with infrared remotes and Arduino with the IRemote library. Various remote controls use different codes, so I designed a device to read them easily.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20 %

Notes:

Prints easily without raft or support. The model is designed for ABS and accounts for ABS shrinkage.

Necessary Components
  • Arduino compatible 5 V board which will fit this form factor. I used a BTE13-010A Pro Mini, which is cheap clone of Arduino Pro with ATMega168 5 V chip at 16 MHz, but you can use anything that runs on 5V.
  • TSOP4838 IR sensor.
  • 8x 7-segment display module based on MAX7219 to display result
  • 30x70 mm prototyping PCB
  • DC jack suitable for your power supply
  • USB to serial converter for programming
Electrical Connection

The electrical connection is pretty straightforward, as there are just three modules to connect. Use the following pins of Arduino:

  • 2 to LED display DIN or Data IN
  • 3 to LED display CS or Load
  • 4 to LED display CLK
  • 5 to IR receiver DATA
  • RAW to DC jack positive
  • GND to ground on DC jack, IR sensor and LED display
  • VCC to VCC on IR sensor and LED display
Programming

The code itself is also pretty simple. It reads the value and displays it as 8-digit hexadecimal number on the LED display.

Mechanical Build

The LED display and universal boards are held in place by M2.5 screws. The IR sensor is placed in the hole and sealed with hot glue.

The parts of case are screwed together, again with M2.5 screws.

title: Improved filament guide tube holder for Replicator 2

description.text:
Improved mount for the filament guide tube on the Replicator 2. Simply click it onto the original mount, no extra tools needed. The original mount for the guide tube is very close to the casing and has several issues;
  • The tube sometimes comes loose
  • It's hard to quickly change filament, for example mid-print, because of the small tube opening
  • Filament tends to jump off from full spools, wrapping around the spool axle
  • Filament sometimes tangles itself, because the straw pulls it towards the sides
    • Inspired on some other existing things, combining all their benefits into one, I am trying to solve all these problems at once. There are 2 slots for guide tubes, in case you use dual extrusion. Each slot has it's own 2 openings on the bottom where filament can be fed from either spool.
    As these openings are shaped like funnels, it's easier to insert filament. And because these openings are positioned over 30mm backwards, they are easier to reach, while they spool the filament more from the center instead of pulling to the side.

• Changed the bridge between both legs to be arced,and reduce overhang problems
  • Greatly improved grip on the filament guide tube.
  • Redid the tubes to have a slightly larger inner diameter and smoother inner surface
Prints without support.

The purpose of this bracket is to fasten an extrusion rail such as V-SLOT™ to a surface. For example, these are used to fasten the "Customizable Linear Carriage Generator" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1411601) to the wooden base of the device.

To generate this bracket, open the "Parameters.scad" file with OpenScad and modify the parameters to suit your needs. The parameter extraExtrusionHeight rises further more the extrusion. Open "Extrusion Mounting Bracket.scad" with OpenScad, render it, export the model and print it.

You will need a T-Slot insert and a screw to fasten it to the extrusion rail.
